slides.title: Introduction to the Policy File
slides.notes: Welcome to the introduction of the Policy File in Guidewire's PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to this session where we dive into the Policy File within Guidewire PolicyCenter. As developers, understanding how policies are structured and managed is crucial for configuring and customizing the application to meet business needs. We'll explore how PolicyCenter organizes and handles policy details, and how these relate to the overall InsuranceSuite.
slides.ocrText: The Policy File

slides.title: Visual Overview of Policy Structure
slides.notes: Image depicting the structure of a policy and its major components in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Here, we have a visual representation of a policy's structure in PolicyCenter. This will serve as a roadmap as we explore each component in detail. Understanding this hierarchy is key for effective data manipulation and UI configuration.

slides.title: Understanding the Policy File
slides.notes: A closer look at the composition of a policy file and its significance.
slides.narration: The policy file is essentially the digital representation of an insurance contract. It houses all the critical components, from general info to specific coverages. As developers, we'll often engage with these elements when implementing business rules or modifying user interfaces.

slides.title: The Policy Summary Page
slides.originalNotes:
Policy Summary
The Policy Summary page can help a Customer Service Representative (CSR) or an underwriter recall details about a specific policy- The details might help a CSR answer questions about the policy or could help the underwriter know the customer’s policy history. The PolicySummary screen is read-only and provides a view into the policy. If you want to edit policy details, use the Policy Info screen.
slides.notes:
Policy Summary
The Policy Summary page can help a Customer Service Representative (CSR) or an underwriter recall details about a specific policy- The details might help a CSR answer questions about the policy or could help the underwriter know the customer’s policy history. The PolicySummary screen is read-only and provides a view into the policy. If you want to edit policy details, use the Policy Info screen.
slides.narration: The Policy Summary page is a read-only interface designed to provide quick access to key policy details. It's particularly useful for CSRs and underwriters who need to reference policy information without altering it. For developers, this is typically where we ensure the right data is displayed through PCF configurations.

slides.title: Defining a Policy
slides.originalNotes:
Policies
A policy is an electronic file where PolicyCenter stores information that is part of the legal contract. A policy is associated with an account, which is covered in more detail in another module.
slides.notes:
Policies
A policy is an electronic file where PolicyCenter stores information that is part of the legal contract. A policy is associated with an account, which is covered in more detail in another module.
slides.narration: Policies are at the heart of PolicyCenter, representing the contractual agreement between an insurer and insured. Each policy is tied to an account, and our role often involves defining how policies are created, stored, and retrieved efficiently within the system.

slides.title: Contacts and Locations
slides.originalNotes:
Contacts and Locations
A contact is a person or organization which includes, but is not limited to, the named insured(s).
A location is a physical location which may be referenced in a policy.
Contacts and locations can either be created on an account and reused on the policy or created on policy.
slides.notes:
Contacts and Locations
A contact is a person or organization which includes, but is not limited to, the named insured(s).
A location is a physical location which may be referenced in a policy.
Contacts and locations can either be created on an account and reused on the policy or created on policy.
slides.narration: Contacts and locations are integral to a policy's context. They can be defined at the account level and reused across multiple policies, or created specifically for a policy. Understanding their roles helps in designing seamless integrations and ensuring data integrity across related entities.
slides.ocrText:
| Contacts and Locations

slides.title: Exploring Policy Lines
slides.originalNotes:
Policy lines
The majority of the "contents" of the policy (the coverables, the coverages, and coverage terms, and so on) are captured under the policy line.
Sample lines of business are available in the PolicyCenter base configuration, such as personal auto, business owners, and so on.
slides.notes:
Policy lines
The majority of the "contents" of the policy (the coverables, the coverages, and coverage terms, and so on) are captured under the policy line.
Sample lines of business are available in the PolicyCenter base configuration, such as personal auto, business owners, and so on.
slides.narration: Policy lines are where the bulk of policy-specific data resides, including coverables and coverages. These lines represent different lines of business like personal auto or business owners. As developers, customizing these lines to match business requirements is a common task.

| Policy lines

slides.title: Understanding Coverables
slides.originalNotes:
Coverables
A coverable is a risk exposure that can be protected by the policy, such as:
The policy line itself.
Tangible property item such as a building or vehicle. Jurisdiction.
slides.notes:
Coverables
A coverable is a risk exposure that can be protected by the policy, such as:
The policy line itself.
Tangible property item such as a building or vehicle. Jurisdiction.
slides.narration: Coverables are the entities within a policy that can be insured, ranging from tangible items like vehicles to intangibles like liability. These are defined within policy lines and are essential for determining what risks are covered and how policies are rated.
slides.ocrText:
| Coverables

Acoverable is a risk exposure that can be protected by the policy

=| A

Vehicle Building

Jurisdiction

slides.title: Coverages Explained
slides.originalNotes:
Coverages
A coverage is protection from a specific risk and is always attached to a coverable.

Coverages can be at the policy line level or for a specific coverable.
For example:
A liability coverage on a policy line protects the insured.
A collision property coverage protects the vehicle.
A dwelling fire coverage protect the building.
slides.notes:
Coverages
A coverage is protection from a specific risk and is always attached to a coverable.

Coverages can be at the policy line level or for a specific coverable.
For example:
A liability coverage on a policy line protects the insured.
A collision property coverage protects the vehicle.
A dwelling fire coverage protect the building.
slides.narration: Coverages are the specific protections offered by a policy for identified risks or coverables. They can be broad or specific, such as liability or collision coverage. Configuring these correctly ensures accurate risk assessment and premium calculations.
slides.ocrText:
| Coverages Gi

slides.title: Coverage Terminology
slides.originalNotes:
Coverage terminology
There are two types of coverages: property and liability.
slides.notes:
Coverage terminology
There are two types of coverages: property and liability.
slides.narration: In PolicyCenter, coverages are categorized mainly as property or liability. Understanding these distinctions is crucial when developing rules or UI components that need to handle these coverage types differently.

slides.title: Defining Coverage Terms
slides.originalNotes:
Coverage Terms
A coverage term is a value that further limits or defines the coverage.

For example, the collision coverage on a vehicle has two coverage terms: deductible and limit.
slides.notes:
Coverage Terms
A coverage term is a value that further limits or defines the coverage.

For example, the collision coverage on a vehicle has two coverage terms: deductible and limit.
slides.narration: Coverage terms like deductibles and limits add specificity to coverages. They are vital parameters in defining the conditions under which coverage is applied and are key elements in the rating engine's calculations.
slides.ocrText:
| Coverage Terms

slides.title: Calculating Premiums
slides.originalNotes:
Premium
Premium is the money that the insured pays for the policy. The rating engine calculates the cost for anything with a price on the policy, such as a coverage.
slides.notes:
Premium
Premium is the money that the insured pays for the policy. The rating engine calculates the cost for anything with a price on the policy, such as a coverage.
slides.narration: Premiums are calculated based on coverages and their associated terms. The rating engine leverages these details to compute the cost, making it crucial for developers to ensure all inputs are accurately captured and configured.
slides.ocrText:
| Premium

Premium is the money that the insured
pays for the policy

slides.title: Role of Forms
slides.originalNotes:
Forms
A form is a document detailing some aspect of the policy. Forms are specific and contain legal information about a policy. Forms are part of the policy contract.
Examples
Declaration sheets.
Base forms.
Additional coverage forms.
Exclusion forms.
slides.notes:
Forms
A form is a document detailing some aspect of the policy. Forms are specific and contain legal information about a policy. Forms are part of the policy contract.
Examples
Declaration sheets.
Base forms.
Additional coverage forms.
Exclusion forms.
slides.narration: Forms are the legal documents that encapsulate policy terms and conditions. They range from declaration sheets to exclusion forms. Ensuring these are correctly generated and associated with policies is a key responsibility when configuring PolicyCenter.
slides.ocrText:
| Forms

=OjA

A form is a physical document detailing
an aspect of a policy

slides.title: Configuring Policy Forms
slides.notes: Understanding how forms are configured and associated with policies.
slides.narration: Configuring forms involves defining templates and ensuring they dynamically generate accurate policy information. This process often requires customization to reflect specific business rules and regulatory requirements.

slides.title: Integrating Policy Data
slides.notes: How policy data is integrated with external systems.
slides.narration: Integration patterns for policy data involve using APIs and messaging systems to synchronize data with external systems. This is essential for maintaining data consistency and supporting business processes that span multiple platforms.

slides.title: Policy Data Model
slides.notes: Understanding the underlying data model for policies in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: The data model for policies is built on core entities like PolicyPeriod, PolicyLine, and Coverage. Familiarity with these entities and their relationships is critical for developers when designing queries, business rules, and customizations.

slides.title: Customizing PolicyCenter
slides.notes: Best practices for customizing policy-related functionalities.
slides.narration: Customizing PolicyCenter involves extending the data model, modifying PCFs, and implementing business rules in Gosu. Adhering to best practices ensures maintainability and performance of the application.

slides.title: PolicyCenter UI Patterns
slides.notes: Exploring user interface patterns within PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: UI patterns in PolicyCenter, such as tabbed views and summary screens, play a crucial role in user experience. As developers, understanding these patterns helps in creating intuitive and efficient interfaces.

slides.title: Policy Lifecycle Management
slides.notes: Managing the lifecycle of a policy from creation to renewal.
slides.narration: Policy lifecycle management encompasses the entire journey of a policy, from issuance to renewal or cancellation. Developers need to ensure that each phase is seamlessly integrated into PolicyCenter through workflow configurations and business rules.

slides.title: Security and Access Control
slides.notes: Implementing security measures for policy data.
slides.narration: Security in PolicyCenter involves controlling access to policy data through role-based permissions and data masking. Developers configure these settings to protect sensitive information while ensuring authorized access.

slides.title: Testing Policy Configurations
slides.notes: Approaches to testing policy configurations in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Testing in PolicyCenter requires a thorough approach, involving unit tests, integration tests, and user acceptance tests. Developers should ensure that all customizations are robust and meet business requirements before deployment.

slides.title: Troubleshooting and Debugging
slides.notes: Techniques for troubleshooting and debugging policy-related issues.
slides.narration: Troubleshooting in PolicyCenter often involves analyzing logs, using the PolicyCenter Debugger, and understanding transaction bundles. Mastery of these techniques is essential for resolving issues efficiently and maintaining system stability.

slides.title: Summary and Next Steps
slides.notes: Recap of key takeaways and a preview of the next lesson on Product Model Introduction.
slides.narration: As we wrap up this lesson on the Policy File in PolicyCenter, remember the key components like policies, coverages, and forms. These elements form the backbone of insurance management in PolicyCenter. Next, we'll explore the Product Model, where we define the products that these policies are built upon, enhancing your understanding of the entire insurance lifecycle.
